definition: body/life/oneself/personally/one's morality and conduct/the main part of a structure or body/pregnant/classifier for sets of clothes: suit, twinset/Kangxi radical 158

sentences.english: He said he swam away from the ship without even getting his hair wet.
sentences.chinese: 他说他游离船身甚至连头发都没有湿。

sentences.english: The soft relaxation armchairs surround a huge fire timbale burning in the fireproofed hull of the vessel.
sentences.chinese: 柔软的休闲扶椅围绕着防火船身里一个巨大的烤火处。

sentences.english: A ship is only half submerged.
sentences.chinese: 船身只有一半浸在水里。

sentences.english: The sudden canting of the ship had made the deck no place for running on;
sentences.chinese: 船身突然倾倒使甲板上没有地方可以躲闪。

sentences.english: The sudden canting of the ship had made the deck no place for running on;
sentences.chinese: 船身忽然倾倒使甲板上没有地方可以躲闪。

sentences.english: Three days at sea convinced me the double-hull theory was wrong.
sentences.chinese: 在海上试航三天后，我就确信双层船身理论是错误的。

sentences.english: The hull's iron plates deep below the waterline were hit by torpedos.
sentences.chinese: 吃水线下的船身铁板被鱼雷击穿。

sentences.english: The Glowworm hit at full force and embedded her bows solidly into the Hipper.
sentences.chinese: 萤火虫号全力一撞，船头牢牢插入希珀号船身。

sentences.english: Tossing the sailboat to and fro as it lay berthed in a secluded lagoon.
sentences.chinese: 船锚在一个隐蔽的湖岔，风不停地来回摇晃着船身。

sentences.english: The hull is only joined together by nails, so you can't have one high sail.
sentences.chinese: 由于船身只是用钉子钉在一起的，所以你不能用高帆。

sentences.english: Flying boat n. A large seaplane that floats on its hull rather than on pontoons.
sentences.chinese: 一种以船身而不以浮筒滑行的巨大的水上飞机。

sentences.english: Standard cannonballs have the longest range and are good at putting holes into hulls.
sentences.chinese: 标准的炮弹可以长距离击中目标，破坏敌方船身。

sentences.english: The tug nearly turned turtle twice, but I managed to keep her upright.
sentences.chinese: 拖船两次都差点翻个儿，但我设法稳住了船身。

sentences.english: So we dropt anchor, and swung round towards the shore.
sentences.chinese: 这样，虽然船抛了锚，但是船身向着海岸摇摆着。

definition: sides of a ship/ship's railing/fig. the dividing line between shipboard expenses and onshore freight charges
the bow or prow of a ship
